text: You had a few minutes to get yourself comfortable with the words on that paper.  Those are all words that – not all of them we’re going to use today, but as we introduce the unit today, those are all words that you will see over the next couple weeks.  What I’m going to ask you to do now is I’m going to ask you actually tuck your word search into your desk. Okay, as soon as you’re done, eyes up here, please. text: Thank you, sir.  Student J.  Remember, I should only have to say something once and you follow the directions.  Okay. And before we get started, up here is our goal for the day. So at any point I ever say to you, Student M, what are we trying to learn today, it’s up there, so you know what we have to do.  Okay? So in our new unit we’re learning the shape of data, or day- ta.  People say it two different ways.  Raise your hand if you’ve heard it “data.”  Raise your hand if you’ve heard “day-ta.”  Okay.  So everybody’s heard it in a different way.  It means the same thing.  It’s spelled the same way. So what we’re going to have to learn today is you’re going to be able to describe or explain how and why we collect data.  Okay/ And you’re going to be able to explain a line plot.  Raise your hand if you did a line plot in third grade.  You did. Good. It’s a [inaudible] into some graphs, getting us into bar graphs.  It looks like a bar graph but without the bar.  It has the X’s all the way up.  You might be familiar with those.  If not, we’re going to do one today.  You’re actually going to create one with boxes of raisins.  Okay?
